"Uhm... I was not looking for humor in your response, shitface. I know you don't hate me, because I doubt you'd even have thhhe self control to not punch me to deathhh. Fine, I will find answers elsewhere."

event.name: SOCIALIZE_ALKALI_GENERIC_4
event.text:
You notice some odd drawings of creatures and evolutionary trees hung up in Alkali's room as if they were part of an evidence board. Alkali catches you staring at them and answers your unspoken questions. "I am renowned for my scientific genius in thhhe galactic community for my work in genetic studies and thhhe engineering of several advanced lifeforms, with thhhe Morphhhs of course being my latest project. However, thhhhat pales in comparison to my TRUE mission. A breakthhhrough so major... so huge it would shake thhhe very foundations of our existence."
Alkali pauses for dramatic effect, clearly proud of just how important whatever he's about to say next is. "I first gained prominence in thhhe Science District for my study into thhhhe history of the Shell and Slug species, specifically trying to find our common ancestor.
Thhhe problem is... I couldn't. No one could. Thhhere's no fossil records. No artifacts, not even cave paintings. Zero evidence of any transitional period. With such distinct biology you would thhink thhhere would be... somethhhing. Thhhis lead to my greatest hypothhhesis. Thhhere seems to be evidence suggesting thhhhere was TAMPERING in thhhe evolution of thhhe Slug species. As if thhhey were just... spliced togethhher from Shell and alien DNA. This is corroborated by thhhe fact thhhe telepathhhhic abilities of thhhe Slugs is unlike anythhhing seen in any othhhher species in the Multiverse. Thhhey contain biochemistry found on our homeworlds, but also thhhat of something unlike anythhhing we've ever seen elsewhere in thhhe Multiverse. Thhhere HAS to be more, and I'm going to find out what. And when I do, thhhere won't be a single person alive able to refute my genius!"

event.name: SOCIALIZE_ALKALI_GENERIC_5
event.text: You spot Alkali leafing through a stack of old letters, and briefly catch the name "Kordet Kip'y" before Alkali stashes them away again.

Alkali seems a bit startled, and his voice is wavering. You can tell he's sad, but he's trying to hide it underneath his usual tone of annoyed indifference. "Mistakes from thhhe past. Love is a pointless thhhing. A chemical reaction thhhhat makes you do stupid, rash thhhings in pursuit of a happiness you'll never find. It's an easy trap to fall for. Luckily, my work helps keep me distracted from such pointless and dangerous pursuits."

choice.text: That's a bad way of looking at it.

event.text: Alkali scoffs. "Well, Renegades are known for thhhheir promiscuous flaunting of sexual favors. I doubt someone like you would have enough control over your cognitive functions to inhibit lust and love. I'm a scientist and a genius, I'm more qualified about thhhis thhhan you are, asshole. Just... get out of my room."

Alkali doesn't seem comforted at all by your agreeance. "You're only agreeing because you were probably hurt real bad by some whore in a brothhhel somewhere. I've reached thhhis conclusion through years of careful analysis and scientific thhheory. I don't just THHHINK love is bad, I have PROVEN it. Now, get out of my room."

event.name: SOCIALIZE_ALKALI_OOJ_1
event.text: You catch Alkali eyeing OOJ, who is wiggling pointlessly in the middle of the hallway. "Look at it. Biological perfection, thhhe ultimate weapon, thhhe ultimate utility. It was created to phase out an entire generation of worthhhless nothhhings. You're very lucky, Renegade, you have bothhh thhhe greatest biological marvel aboard your ship AND its creator."

choice.text: OOJ isn't an 'it', or a weapon. He's a person too.

event.text: "AHAHAHAHAHAH! HAHAHAHAH! Oh. You're not joking. God what are you, some kind of humanitarian? Some pro-life bullshit propagandist? IT was born in a lab, made in a test tube. Thhhhings born in labs are not PEOPLE. Unless thhhey're Shells. Or uh... the vitro-fertilized. Okay - maybe you have a point. But only maybe. I will conduct a greater hypothhhesis on thhhhis later, if only just to prove you wrong."

"Good, I was getting afraid you weren't going to respond. It's not often people outside of my laboratory staff get to interact with me, so take in thhhe view and stunning genius of my commentary while you can. It won't last forever!" Alkali rolls away.
Awkwardly, Alkali laughs to himself. "Yep... real lucky..." Alkali rolls away, not sure what to make of your silence.

event.name: SOCIALIZE_ALKALI_OOJ_2
event.text: You catch OOJ and Alkali deep in a conversation, speaking gibberish back and forth. You're fairly surprised to see this, because as far as you knew no one could understand what they're saying. Though, if anyone could, it makes sense to be Alkali.

choice.text: You know what the Morphs are saying, Alkali?

event.text: Alkali turns to you, annoyed by your interuption. "What? No. I never finished pathhhing thhhe right neurons for thhhem to communicate properly. It's baffling thhhey can 'speak' at all. I'm probing for patterns, some kind of indication it's a real language thhhey're speaking and not nonsense. Thhhe results are inconclusive... but not discouraging. If I can't crack thhhis damn code, thhhere's no one else in thhhe Multiverse thhhhat can! So go away and let me concentrate. Thhhhis isn't an easy or quick process."

event.name: SOCIALIZE_ALKALI_FREDDY_1
event.text:
Alkali rolls up to Freddy and begins observing him silently as he drinks his tea. Freddy stares back for a few moments before he puts down his saucer. "Pardon my intrusion, but might I inquire what it is you're uhm... Doing?
"Observing. You're quite thhhhe strange specimen. All prior Mantis I have observed are incredibly unintelligent, to a comedically distressing degree. You, however, appear to be at least of an average intelligence. Would you mind if I dissected your brain later to discover what genetic mutation occurred thhhat lifted your IQ from thhhhat of a potato?"
"Well that's quite rude. Are you always like this, or do you just have something against my species?"
"Oh nonsense, I view all barbarian species equally. Thhhey all serve places in thhhe galaxy, but I hardly thhhink you should mind my gentle prodding. I find Mantis often admire my vast intellect!"
Freddy says nothing more to Alkali but turns to you. "Where did we find this asshole again? And may I vent him?"

event.name: SOCIALIZE_ALKALI_ARIADNE_1
event.text:
You hear a high pitched scream come from the other end of the ship and rush to find the source. When you arrive, you find Ariadne has grabbed Alkali by the arm and is holding him in the air. As he squirms and squirms to be let free, Ariadne glowers at him. When Alkali notices you've arrived he pleads for you to help. "Please, thhhhe vicious brute has gone mad and is trying to kill me! Tell it to let go at once! Thhhe Multiverse cannot afford to lose my genius!"
You glance up at Ariadne who grunts. "This little mold spore just thought it funny to call me a man because I was ugly. I thought I should smash his face open with my fist, but maybe he'd rather I throw him out the window instead."
Alkali speaks up, as if insulted Ariadne should insinuate such a thing. "Oh nonsense, I made no such claim! I requested thhhe knowledge as to if your species were hermaphhhrodites. I know very well you are a woman, but as thhhe Slugs go, gender is but a social construct inherited from thhhe Union! I was merely wondering since you do take on thhhe appearance of a male and-"
Ariadne smacks Alkali against the ground and kicks him against a wall, where he lays in a daze. Though tempted to allow Ariadne to continue beating him up, you can't afford to let her kill him and reluctantly ask her to calm down.

event.name: SOCIALIZE_ALKALI_ELLIE_1
event.text:
Ellie and Alkali are sat next to each other in the break room, with a diagram in front of them. Alkali seems to be trying to explain something about inheritance and alleles to Ellie using the diagram, but instead she's doodling a horse on the paper with a pink crayon. Unlike his typical behavior however, Alkali doesn't seem annoyed, if not perhaps a bit exasperated by his lack of understanding of her behavior.
"You are... remarkably unconventional, professor Ellie. N-not thhhat thhhat's a bad thing! We need unconventional science to build the future, and you've done marvelous work with your Quarp Juice! It's just... I was wondering if you had your own thhhoughts to add on my research. There are few scientists whose opinions I respect enough to review my work, but yours I most certainly do!"
"Ssshh... Ellie's drawing a horsie!"
"Yes, yes... but after you're done drawing the Equinoid, could you look over my paper?"
"Sure thing! Ellie'll do anything for a fan!"
Alkali seems relieved. "Good, good! Well I won't disturb you in the meantime..." Alkali rolls away, taking one last long look at Ellie as he goes.

event.name: SOCIALIZE_TYRDEO_NOTHING
event.text: "Oh heavens! You startled me Captain! Sorry, I was about to start meditating. It helps calm my anxiety. Maybe we can talk later, then?"

event.name: SOCIALIZE_TYRDEO_GENERIC_1
event.text: Tyrdeo slithers past, humming a song in his native language that doesn't pass well through your translator. Curious about it, you ask him what the song is. "Oh, this little tune? It's just one from my childhood! We used to sing it on the playground as kids! So much nostalgia..."

"Oh, it's the song the revolutionaries sang when they murdered Oertiss! It's about passing around the embalmed segments of his organs. The third and fourth melody are about the story of an argument about who got his liver!" Tyrdeo doesn't seem to think this sort of song is inappropriate for children, and goes back to singing as he carries on his way.

event.name: SOCIALIZE_TYRDEO_GENERIC_2
event.text: Strangely, several portraits of Tyrdeo have been mysteriously appearing around the ship, decorating various hallways and rooms. It's frankly obvious who's hanging them up, but you aren't sure what you want to do about it.

"Oh... I uh... heh... uhm..." Tyrdeo seems caught off-guard, unsure how to justify his narcissism. "Sorry, I've been practicing my painting. It's hard to do gardening aboard a spaceship so I wanted to find other venues of artistic expression. I'll uh... I'll take the paintings down. I'm sorry." Tyrdeo seems genuinely apologetic and slithers away to go take care of the situation.

You pull the paintings off the wall and start stacking them in a pile. While the technique seems a bit amateur, you can tell painstaking effort went into each of them. Tyrdeo eventually notices you taking them down and stares woefully at the pile, not having enough courage to do anything about it.

event.name: SOCIALIZE_TYRDEO_GENERIC_3
event.text: "I think some species are quite strange in the characteristics they look for in a leader!" Tyrdeo shakes his head. "The Republic has been down on its luck - I swear, I was trying! - But I find the leaders of more functional nations to still be quite silly! What do people see in Lumei or Wentworth or..." Tyrdeo hesitates his next words. "Well... Nights, I guess. I don't want to slander my ally but... he's a bit gruff, you know? It sure was nice to have another leader in that room who was gay, but god did he drink like the world was about to end!" You can tell if you don't stop him now, Tyrdeo's about to open the floodgates to ranting.

"And god did he smell! He smelled terrible, awful, truly miserable. I heard he was once quite attractive and cunning back in the day. I got to see that Gregory at least a little bit, but things sure went downhill fast! The excesses of the Kleptocracy, it's ridiculous how much they waste! Spending billions funding government-run pleasure cruises and casinos and bars, and... and they drink and they gamble and by god! How do they manage to stay afloat? The Kleptocracy should be in ruins like the Republic if they've really been running themselves this way all this time! It's a shame Slocknog thought it wise to invade us, because I had heard great things about him before that!"

"And Nights wasn't even the worst of them! When he wasn't absolutely wasted I actually appreciated his wit sometimes, he could be quite funny and charming! But god, Toarde? The Rockman? By the sweet heavens was he ever a snooze! Always talking about the next move, the next plan, the next battle, bla bla bla. Business, business, business. No rapport, and I swear by golly did I try to have some! Nights and Leik and I would go off on outings sometimes, spend time in each other's nations, get to know each other - but Toarde never came! He's just an unbearable asshole, and the atrocities he comits in his homeland?! It's despicable! I thought the Coalition was supposed to be about a new and better future for the galaxy, but if Toarde was in charge, there sure wouldn't be anything better in his galaxy! Leik was nice though. I could always tell she had more underneath her charisma, trying to weasel what she wanted out of everything, but who can blame her? She never trusted Nights and Nights never trusted her, but she was always gushing with me! Maybe it was because the Republic sided with the Hive during the Federation-Mantis war? Not many did, besides the Confederacy."

"It's funny, now that I think about it. How casual our meetings were whenever Toarde was out on some other business. Nights was such a party-goer, Leik was always so forthcoming and kind, and I'm certainly not against a bit of fun every now and then... you'd almost think we were friends! And... maybe in another life we could have been? I don't have many friends! It was so nice. I was always aware I was only there by circumstance... just a stroke of luck. I know they were pulling my strings, getting me to do what they wanted. But if that's what it takes to save the Republic then I'll do what I must! I'll do anything to save the Republic, to save my people! I was a good President, god damn it! I did everything I could! I may not be the brightest but I'm no Oertiss, Aerkae, or Kaero!" Tyrdeo starts to break down, but collects himself enough to not cry in front of you. "Oh heavens, I'm very sorry Captain! I've been talking for quite a while... I'll go now."

choice.text: Tell him you have to go.

event.text: "Oh! Of course, Captain. Well, I'll see you around sometime then! Bye bye!"

event.name: SOCIALIZE_TYRDEO_GENERIC_4
event.text: "Do you think maybe we could hire some servants, Captain? To assist with preparing food and making our beds and you know, pointless manual labor? I can't imagine they're too costly, maybe only a salary of a couple hundred scrap for a cheap one. We'd need at least 4 or 5, of course, but it would be manageable, right? Right?" You say nothing, instead staring at Tyrdeo to determine if he's joking or not. "Right... well, I'll take this uncomfortable silence as a no then. Sorry for the trouble. Heheh..."

event.name: SOCIALIZE_TYRDEO_GENERIC_5
event.text: "I've heard the Confederacy has a little movement going on, trying to rally support to join the Coalition. I did always wonder if that was going to happen, since the Confederates did support the Hive during the war. What a strange and volatile place we live in. Do you ever think of other galaxies, and what they're like? We have all this fancy Multiverse travel and yet no one's ever been to another galaxy. I'm no spaceologist or astronomologist or whatever they're called but I do think about it quite often. What if we're living in the bad galaxy? Hmmm..."

event.name: SOCIALIZE_TYRDEO_TURZIL_1
event.text: Tyrdeo slithers up to you in the break room and takes a seat across from you. "I don't mean to sound gossipy here but I'm simply quite curious... about that Engi we have aboard. Turzil, yes? He's so very... peculiar? I'm familiar with all shades of peculiar of course, but it's... well, hmm, how do I say this. He's not very social, is he?"

"Well, I heard he was aspiring in some form of art. I happen to be rather partial to a portrait or two of myself, and I asked if he might paint me! He said yes, although somewhat reluctantly, and he just kept apologizing the whole time that he wouldn't do a good job! The poor boy, heavens, I wasn't trying to intimidate him. Then when he was finished and gave me the painting I told him it was beautiful, which was certainly no lie, and he just shut down! Dear... I don't believe I said anything wrong to him." Tyrdeo shakes his head. "Hmmm, Engi. Such strange creatures. Never met one quite like him though."

event.name: SOCIALIZE_TYRDEO_OOJ_WEALSEY_1
event.text: A ruckus of screaming from the other room leads you to Tyrdeo with his tongue plunged deep into OOJ's squishy and slimy body, fishing around and tugging. "HELP! HELP! OH GOD OH HEAVENS THE MONSTER HAS EATEN MY DEAR WEALSEY! MY PRECIOUS BIRD! Please Captain, help me! Heeeeelp!" Tyrdeo begins to sob, still struggling to fish the bird from out of OOJ.

You stand next to Tyrdeo and reach your arm into OOJ, fishing around in the suspiciously spacious cavern within. You feel all sorts of sharp metal, or maybe glass, what might be part of a Mantis exoskeleton, and many more things you can't even begin to guess at. Finally, you feel a plump and squishy, bird-like object and grab it, pulling Wealsey out from the gelatinous Morph. For having just been eaten, Wealsey looks surprising okay, and flutters to the top of Tyrdeo's head and tweets. "Oh sweet grace be this day. I thought I had lost him forever! Thank you Captain. Why- why do we let this thing roam the hallways? It's dangerous!" OOJ jiggles again, as if insulted. "Parra para tik spikle mika pallajoo! Piss."

choice.text: Tell OOJ to spit Wealsey out.

event.text: "Pakook malahoo kooj kooj!" OOJ vibrates and wiggles, and moments later spits out a yellow blob onto the floor. For having just been eaten, Wealsey looks surprising okay, and flutters to the top of Tyrdeo's head and tweets. "Oh sweet grace be this day. I thought I had lost him forever! Thank you Captain. Why- why do we let this thing roam the hallways? It's dangerous!" OOJ jiggles again, as if insulted. "Parra para tik spikle mika pallajoo! Piss."

Admist your cruel teasing Tyrdeo continues to pull. Somehow, whether it's OOJ reaching an understanding of the situation or just random chance, the grey blob decides to finally release the bird from his grasp. Wealsey seems surprisingly okay and tweets in greatings to his Leech father, who lifts the bird cautiously and places him between his crown and slithers away without glancing back at either of you.

event.name: SOCIALIZE_ALKRAM_NOTHING
event.text: Alkram is laying in shock in his room. At first, he doesn't respond to you, but eventually you get his attention. "Why are you snapping at me? Can't you see I'm having a moment... When you get to be my age, and have seen the things I've seen, sometimes you need to just... stop for a while and think. And that thinking means not being disturbed."

event.name: SOCIALIZE_ALKRAM_GENERIC_1
event.text: Alkram seems particularly bothered by some thought of his, and angrily vents in your general direction but not necessarily to you specifically. "Bah, the purity and will of the public conscience is a myth. What this galaxy needs is a set of strong leaders who aren't tainted by democratic notions and have the strength and intelligence to lead us! And I don't mean some bourgeoisie monarchist flakes like Leiiikonpliiinakra or the Elders. I mean someone capable and competent! Those Shells seem to have the right idea. I can't say I'm a fan of their eugenics, but their leadership selection portrays an immense wisdom..."

event.name: SOCIALIZE_ALKRAM_GENERIC_2
event.text: "There are days when I regret the side I took in the Federation-Mantis War. There are days I regret my history as a war-hero. There are many days I mourn the lives of all I took. There are countless days I think of the soldiers that I couldn't save. But there is never a day I regret being a part of the Eargen Republic. We are a divided and downtrodden people, but beneath our endless depression there is a great culture and spirit that is all but lost. We must fight to reclaim it. My ideal Republic is no Federation member, this is true. But it is not of the Coalition either. I think our people simply need some isolation, to ponder our national identity and the values we used to stand for so long ago. And when we have, only then shall we emerge from this darkness as a new, vigorous nation full of life and wellbeing for the galaxy. It is a shame I could not be the one to bring us this future."

event.name: SOCIALIZE_ALKRAM_GENERIC_3
event.text: "In my observations of your behavior I have noticed you lack a great deal of the discipline one would look to find in a good soldier. You lack the uniform and, I think, the nationalist spirit I would expect to see too. Yet, I see the heart and the spirit of one. Tell me Captain, do you see yourself as a soldier?"

choice.text: Yes, I am a soldier of the Federation.

event.text: "I see. I suppose this bears true in both a metaphorical and litteral sense. You do fight for the Federation, although you are a part of no platoon or squadron. Still, I have a great respect for any man or woman who serves a great debt to their nation. Even in my enemies, I can hold no ill will if they fight with true valor for a value they believe in. Such is what a soldier must be."

choice.text: Yes, but a soldier of no allegiance.

event.text: "Hm. Then not a good soldier are you? A soldier is one who fights for a cause, whatever that cause might be. I suppose it's in the name, yes? 'Renegade'. One without an allegiance. But are you then, I wonder, really a soldier at all? Or are you just another soul wandering this cosmos with no true purpose? Fighting for anything that seems right in the moment, but never finding a true ground to believe in. Not to say I know the answer, because I don't. And I doubt you do either. But this is the kind of reflection one must make to really find themself."

"And so scornfully you speak of it! At least, I must assume so for such a strong willed opinion. Yes, I know the type. I am, really, in no position to argue. I am proud to be a soldier, but I would not be proud to bring shame on someone else for not preferring the label."

event.name: SOCIALIZE_ALKRAM_GENERIC_4
event.text:
"There was a dark time in my life when I fell into much the same pit as my Leech brethren. This was shortly after we lost the war, when it felt like the Republic had done the impossible and fallen from grace when it hadn't even had any to begin with. I felt so much shame for who I was and my actions, and so I turned to dark avenues. It never reached, perhaps, the same lengths as many of my kind. But alcohol has a certain allure that seems to draw in and unite all the lost and poor souls in this galaxy. And so I became a drinker. I quit the military and subsided into history, to be forgotten as just another foolish man who thought he had a place in this galaxy. That was, until the Kleptocracy invaded. I could stand the Chrysolic practioners and their invasive monasteries. It was slanderous to our culture, sure, but we Leeches were never a spiritual folk before anyways. But such a brazen attack from an alien foe? I was drawn back into the fray."
Alkram blinks, realizing he's been rambling a bit longer than he had anticipated. "What I mean to say, if you are to take the advice of this old general, is what we think we want and what reality shows us we need to be often lacks symmetry. Every man and woman has a purpose, but that purpose ought to be realized only when we're willing to see it."

event.name: SOCIALIZE_ALKRAM_GENERIC_5
event.text: "I could have been a poet. Or an author. I studied literature a bit, and it fascinated me. The way people commanded words was facsimile to troops on a battlefield. In the command of a strategic and skilled author, language can be deployed with as much deadly precision and destructive - or constructive - power as the greatest militaries in the Multiverse. But it was not to be my calling. War had other ideas. And so I put down my pen and traded it for sword, and the rest is history."

event.name: SOCIALIZE_ALKRAM_GENERIC_6
event.text: "During the Mantis War I had gained little respect and lost plenty for the Confederacy. At that time the Vampweeds seemed disorganized and weak willed. I foresaw their hasty and shameful surrender long before it happened, signing some document of false peace with the Gathering to bail on the war and leave us all to burn. But I can see under the reforms of this new Premier, Ivar, they have become as proud and strong a nation as the Eargen Republic once was in its glory days. Perhaps their ideals are not for me, but that is irrelevant as long as they stay true to them. If this was the Confederacy I had fought alongside in the war, I think just maybe victory would have been our glory to reap."

event.name: SOCIALIZE_ALKRAM_ARIADNE_1
event.text:
Alkram approaches Ariadne, flaring his muscles with electric currents in an effort to appear even tougher and more grissled than usual. "So you are the Rockwoman I have heard so much about! How proud I am to serve aboard this vessel with another with such great revolutionary spirit!"
Ariadne slowly turns away from her work to look at the Leech. "You and I are about as similar as fire is to coffee. I turned away from the life of a princess in the house of one of the most powerful men in the entire known Multiverse to fight in mud and trenches to free people who don't even know they're enslaved from a brutal dictatorship led by 5 of the most cunning and murderous monsters in all of history. YOU are an aging veteran who fought on the side of a tyranical Hive mind in some long-gone war and got bored of eating batteries in a retirement home, so you incited the latest of some dozen revolutions in a fractured Republic against a ditzy and eccentric gardener whose greatest crimes were being culturally insensitive to a flower and using political gain as a cover to making friends."
With each word Ariadne makes a violent jab towards Alkram, who reels back in shock from the sudden hostility. There's a few moments of awkward silence before Alkram hurries away in shame.

event.name: SOCIALIZE_TONY_NOTHING
event.text: You attempt to walk up to Tony to talk, but he just doesn't bother. Instead he sits there staring at you, sadness in his eyes. You begin to feel miserable as well, and can't bear to be around any longer. Hopefully, this will fade soon.

event.name: SOCIALIZE_TONY_GENERIC_1
event.text: While divying up tasks to the rest of the crew for typical ship maintenance, you notice Tony isn't around. You send someone out to look for him, but they report they can't find him anywhere. He's not in the restrooms, the cargo bay, his room, or the dining area where he normally is. Worried, you have just one other idea where he might be. You head to the ship's fuel tank, where Tony is busy emptying it into barrels. "Uhm... hello. Look, I understand what this looks like, but fuel is about to spike in price due to this war - if we sell it off at the peak and wait a few months, we could triple our fuel reserves!"

choice.text: And lose the war in this universe?

event.text: "Yes, yes, THIS universe. What's one of an infinite number of them being lost, when you could make a profit? I swear, you let me on your ship, but you never want my help."

event.name: SOCIALIZE_TONY_GENERIC_2
event.text: "In the corporate world, you don't make very many friends. Well, unless you consider fusing two species together "making" friends. So I got to thinking, what better way to make my store stand out than to pretend to be Tony Sr., your friendly neighborhood galactic marketplace owner? Now, the veneer has long since fallen off, but Tony's has locations in every free market nation in the Multiverse. But had I known how it'd all end, cornered by an Angel... I think I'd have hired more body doubles."

event.name: SOCIALIZE_TONY_GENERIC_3
event.text: "Ah, there you are. I was just going over my plans for the newest branch of the company - Tony Senior's Senior Helpline. I've noticed that the bulk of our support calls are from senior citizens, and so I've come up with a way to cut costs on them. We train a small team to make callers think they're smarter than the employee they're talking to, and offer to hire them after they've paid a training fee. The trick is, the fee is more than they'll make before they die of old age, and they get all the calls from seniors that take up our time! Don't you get it? They'll be paying us to give bad advice to each other, AND we don't have to spend time on the elderly!"

"What's so evil about it? They aren't taking that money into whatever afterlife they're stupid enough to believe in, they may as well give it to someone who already has the money to afford anti-aging treatments. If they didn't want to fall into a pyramid scheme in their golden years, they should've tried being rich enough to stay young and beautiful, like me."

event.name: SOCIALIZE_TONY_GENERIC_3_ACCEPT
event.text: "Oh no. If a poor person thinks this is a good idea, maybe I'm in the wrong here? What if they call ME to thank me for their job? I don't want to talk to the elderly, that's why I had my grandmother put away. Eugh, thanks for letting me talk about this idea with you."

event.name: SOCIALIZE_TONY_GENERIC_3_DECLINE
event.text: "Now, you see? That's your conscience talking. It tells you that the ideas that will make you rich are bad, so you don't realize how good it feels to not care about people." Tony slithers away, clearly under the impression he has given you excellent advice. You just hope he doesn't send you a bill for it.

event.name: SOCIALIZE_TONY_GENERIC_4
event.text: You find a stack of recordings underneath one of the cabinets in Tony's room, all clearly marked as blackmail on his business associates. One in particular is marked as 'The Good One'.

"Oh god, ahahahahahah! This guy tried to steal baby food from one of our stores when his business went south, then tripped and broke the jars inside his jacket while he was walking out. So he staggers back in to clean the blood, glass, and baby food off of himself in the bathroom, and bumps right into me! Next thing I know, he's crying for mercy, begging me to not let his kid starve, the whole nine yards - long story short, he didn't have to go to prison, and I got my body double! I guess the moral of the story is, you never know when a great opportunity will knock on your door, so seize it when you can!"

choice.text: Put the tape back and don't ask.

event.name: SOCIALIZE_TONY_GENERIC_5
event.text: Tony is staring out the window of the ship, taking photos of the stars as you travel. It feels odd to see him doing something not inherently sinister.

If there's somehow something unethical going on here, you'd prefer to not have to think about it. Tony chuckles to himself as you walk away... hopefully out of a genuine appreciation for the beauty of the cosmos, but probably not.

"Ah, I just had a brilliant idea while I was reading through some old Earth history. Apparently humans used to sell each other the right to name a star so they could make a quick buck, and it got me thinking. With the Multiverse open to us now, why not sell stars from other universes to people? After all, the average person will never jump universes to check what they ACTUALLY call the star, so it's not like there's a risk to it."

choice.text: But don't they all look the same? What's the difference between the same star in different universes?

event.text: "Wait just a second, that's brilliant! I don't need to take photos of stars across the Multiverse, I can just lie! Now I can get back to growing my business empire, instead of staring at these damnable stars all day." If you had any hope left for Tony becoming a better person, this would have crushed it.

choice.text: Walk away before you give him any more ideas.

event.name: SOCIALIZE_TONY_GENERIC_6
event.text: "Captain, I have a business proposition for you. It's maybe a strange one, but I think it's the best decision you could ever make." Unsure what he's asking for, you inquire further. "I need you to sell me your body, when this is all over. I figure, when the war in this universe is finished, you'll probably have a few minutes of fame as the local savior of the Federation. I could capitalize on that with a museum, but I'd have to act fast, and I'll need something unique to bait people in. And what would be more unique than your actual, taxidermied body? Think about it - people paying money just to look at you - even more if they want to take a picture. Imagine crowds of people lining up to buy plushies that look just like you!"

"Well... would that really be the worst thing? Poor people die all the time, doing stupid things like 'working for a better life' and 'fighting to save their universe'. You already knew you might die against the Flagship, so why not just seal the deal and make yourself a legend? Shit, if I ever die, I know I'd want them to prop me up in the boardroom. What's the point of existing, if not to have your lessers praise you?"

event.name: SOCIALIZE_TONY_BILLY_1
event.text:
Tony appears to be trying to make conversation with Billy. "Hey, Billy, it's been a long time since we've talked, but-"
"Not right now Tony, I'm busssy! Sssshit, I'm late for my 6:05 call!" Billy stumbles and drops one of the 8 phones he's juggling. "SSSSHIT, NOW IT'SSSS BROKEN! God damn it, I can't take thisss sssstress!" Billy turns to Tony. "Tony, if you want to make yourssself ussseful, go get me a coffee, pronto!"
You prepare to watch two impossibly self-important people collide with each other, but instead Tony slithers off to go make Billy his coffee. Flabbergasted, you chase him to ask why he would suck up to Billy. Tony seems confused that you would even ask - "He's richer than me."

Tony shrugs. "There's an order to these things. You'd snap to it and make coffee if a superior officer ordered you to, and I'll do the same for someone richer. It helps grease the wheels between companies if we all know where we stand." Moments later, Tony returns with the coffee. Billy more gracefully accepts. "Oh, by the way, Tony, did you get my messssage about the adjustmentssss to our crossss-promotion?"
"Yes, of course. It all sounds good, though you didn't need to be so formal about it - we're both on the same ship right now, after all."
"Ah, you're right. Sssorry, when you're mailing out a few dozen of thesssse, you forget the finer detailsss. Thanksssss for the coffee, by the way."
Billy runs off as another one of his phones starts to ring, leaving you very confused on how to interpret this reunion.

event.name: SOCIALIZE_TONY_JERRY_1
event.text:
"Hi Mr. Senior! It... it is Mr. Senior, right?" Jerry waves to Tony as he passes.
"Er... yes. Well, kind of. I'm actually Tony Senior Junior. Senior is my last name, but Tony Senior Senior is my father. It's funny, because 'Senior' in my language actually means 'fortuitous'."
Jerry nods. "Language can be quite strange. I didn't know about that though!" You can tell Jerry isn't really that interested, but he's just playing along because he has more to say. "So uh... Tony. I know you're going through some stuff so... just in case you're ever feeling down, just know there's always people there for you, okay? Even in the strangest, most unlikeliest of places there's always people looking out for you. Never underestimate your allies."
Tony is touched but not entirely sold.
Jerry continues, "If you uh... ever forget that... just remember... uhm... even when things look bad Tony, you're never 'alony'." Jerry smiles sheepishly, and Tony bids him a heatfelt thank you.
"To be honest, I think I underestimated you. Not too fond of your uncle, but you seem like a good kid. But, just so you know, alony is a derogatory for a prostitute in my language. So probably not a good idea to go saying that to other Leeches."

event.name: SOCIALIZE_DESSIUS_NOTHING
event.text: "Hark, I grant thee mine finest sorrows, but in this hour I lack the proper words for a conversation in making. Mayhaps you are best in seeking conversation elsewhere until I have regenerated the interest to speak."

event.name: SOCIALIZE_DESSIUS_GENERIC_1
event.text: "Hail, dear Captain, for I come in search of a most curious favor. Would thou provide me with your finest gasses? I am with great certainty holding to the idea that you must possess most enriching gasses aboard this vessel, yes?"

"Yes, for gasses it is that I wish to consume. To assimilate, to become one with myself. A source of both nutrients and steady growth. It shall make me both stronger and wiser. Never mind it, I can see in your face utmost confusion. I will seek the gasses myself, and return with more specifics of my quest later. Farewell."

event.name: SOCIALIZE_DESSIUS_GENERIC_2
event.text: "I hath seen many a fine vessel in the centuries I have lived, Captain. I do say, this vessel may be among them! I too, have a most prized of vessels which someday I hope to pilot. Though, of course, it is not yet available for such a venture. For a little under a century it has sat awaiting its day in my finest shipyards, as its construction commences. Oh great 'Overture', some day your brilliance shall sail the cosmos and awaken all to the greatness of my fine Dynasty!" Dessius beams with pride, thinking of his soon to be flagship. Based on loose Federation intelligence, you've heard a little of this ship. The 'Overture', once finished, will be the largest known spaceship to ever have been constructed. Just be glad Dessius seems to like you and you'll probably never have to see the thing in action.

event.name: SOCIALIZE_DESSIUS_GENERIC_3
event.text: "Both myself and my ancestors have born witness to the evolution of a countless collection of civilization and species. Of the many, a few in mind stand to contest my greater observation. The Zoltans, those intrepid victims of a near self-imposed destruction, once captured my highest fascination. In a strangest of ways it could be said I even... cheered for their success? Something about their dreadful origins and painful ascent made me wish ever more for their highest ascension. But... their history is mired in a great many tragedies. First, the great infighting of generations. Then, the mandate for the abandon of physical form. And now, the rise of a violent and radical rule which threatens to soon outgrow their original, more peacable rule. They remind me of another kind so long ago who once threatened the decimation of this reality and the next over their own self-destructive foolishness. Now, I see only tragedy in the featureless faces of the hard-light ones. Alas, oh damn this curse of eternal memory."

event.name: SOCIALIZE_DESSIUS_GENERIC_4
event.text: "It takes only but a fool to challenge myself in a duel. I hath engaged in combat with the finest of combatants in the Multiverse, and only twice have I been bested." Dessius gets out that last part quickly, clearly not intended to elaborate on his losses. Could be an interesting story though.

"Hmph. Pitiful, is what they were. The first was despite an opponent who had no shame, and which I hardly hesitate to call a victor. A Paladin, whose inquisitionary force came to seek right to conquer the ruins of my people. I accepted a challenge, but I soon found I would not be facing an opponent who knew honorable conduct. Let us say that he... brought a missile launcher to this fair sword fight. It matters not though, for we dealt with the Inquisition swiftly regardless. Perhaps, I admit, putting an end to those zealots was truly one of the Federation's greatest but few achievements."

Dessius lingers in silence a bit too long, before finally releasing his shame. "The second... was against a Slug. It was to settle some trifle territorial manner... but the real stakes were symbolic. I believe many chose to interpret the fight as a match to settle who truly ruled the nebulas in this age. The Slug was swift, he was skilled, and he disarmed me quickly. I relive that match in my memories, or perhaps more correctly my nightmares, nightly. I could have won... and yet I, Dessius Yan Tartodicus, 16th Prime Reaper and greatest swordsman in the Multiverse, was bested by nothing but a common thief? It is a blot on history..."

event.name: SOCIALIZE_DESSIUS_GENERIC_5
event.text: "There is a dreadful fate awaiting this cluster, I can only feel it... But I know it is coming. It is a premonition I have felt in my essence since I first split from the 15th Reaper."

"Did thou not hear me? A dreadful one, I said. Art thou seeking more specifics? If so I'm afraid I do not know... but something deadly is brewing. We are nothing but actors in a far greater plot, I have learned this much. But when will the puppetmasters reveal themselves? We must be ready. I foresee it will happen within your lifetime... And certainly mine, since I shall live for centuries more at least."

"Oh, did I use such terminology? Yes, though such is but a theory. A theory proposed by scientists of an age very very long ago. That perhaps what we know of the Multiverse is in fact only a smaller infinity... in one much, much larger. But for what madman would compare infinities? Certainly not I. I merely foretell the apocalypse coming, as a horseman of the end. But hold your nihilistic fears, for I do not think the end is inevitable. Surely, something must be doable to prevent our demise. What that is though, I hold no such knowledge yet."

event.name: SOCIALIZE_DESSIUS_DEVORAK_1
event.text:
Ferocious clangs of metal fill your ears, guiding you towards the cargobay. There, you find Dessius and Devorak sparring, clashing their swords with furious momentum. "Fear my blade, Zoltan, thou shalt know only defeat against my prowess!"
Devorak says nothing, completely immersed in the duel. Dessius continues to taunt him, but you watch as Devorak seems to slip into a zen-like state. In just three strokes, he parries Dessius' swing, cuts upward, and disarms Dessius. With a metalic rattle the Reaper's sword flies to the opposite end of the room. Dessius is shocked. "So, thou hath bested me. So be it. I have been rendered disarmed. Claim your victory then, Zoltan." Dessius bows.
However, Devorak does not accept his victory. "I do not fight to win, Ghost. I fight for the exhilaration, and the reminder that I am still alive. Even in a friendly duel I am briefly reminded of my mortality. I do not wish to claim this victory. I am satisfied in having fought well against a talented opponent." He bows, and Dessius follows a few moments later.

event.name: SOCIALIZE_DESSIUS_EATER_1
event.text:
Dessius and the Beacon Eater are sat together in Dessius' quarters, staring intently at a set of charts and drawings. "The runes... the meaning cryptic, but this weapon you think dangerous is?"
"Oh hark, most certainly. The legends tell there was a first... but it malfunctioned, and evolved further than was intended most surely by its creators. But that was after the war. We have born witness to it. The destruction it caused... was only secondary to what I hypothesize this may wreck."
The Beacon Eater mulls this information, whatever it means, over. "I have reason no to not trusting you. If intel suggests continued existence, then time is of essence. We must find any traces of weapon, and destroy them.
"Agreed. Perhaps only this may spare us the fate that destroyed the Vesyticcarithe so long ago." Your translator skips over that 'V' word, unable to find an appropriate translation. Whatever is going on in here, it seems you aren't meant to know about it.

event.name: SOCIALIZE_DESSIUS_TONY_1
event.text:
Tony is busy rigging a coin slot to the bathroom doors when Dessius approaches him. "Come with me, oh child of darkness, and let us sing the song of sorrows!" Paralyzed with confusion, Tony manages to choke out a simple "What?"
Dessius is not discouraged. "Through thine grapevine I hath become aware you seek to silence the siren's call of the end. But before you go, let us chant together, and perhaps in a new mind we will find new life and with it new meaning. A poetic symphony that restores the vigor and spirit of once was. Lady darkness is not a mistress most run to meet, but look and you shall find her grasp as comforting as your birth-giver's."
Tony is still utterly confused. "I think my translator is malfunctioning. I... have no clue what you're talking about." Dessius groans, and goes to leave. "I shan't be unwise and hold this against you... but I find it most tiring when such misunderstandings occur. I hope you find the strength to look to your broken spirit, oh miserable one. But I suppose I shan't be the one to find it for you."

event.name: SOCIALIZE_ANOINTED_NOTHING
event.text: On a routine patrol of the ship you stumble across The Anointed gnawing on some loose wires and metal. "Do not worry, I have verified to ensure this is only for an unimportant subsystem. I must sustain my hunger. Please enthuse your interests with other communications besides my own."

event.name: SOCIALIZE_ANOINTED_GENERIC_1
event.text: The Anointed walks past, but stops when she sees you. From her pocket she procures a small black object and hands it to you. "Sustenance." With no other words she wanders away. The object does not appear edible in any capacity.

event.name: SOCIALIZE_ANOINTED_GENERIC_2
event.text: "Captain, perhaps you assist. I must undergo sacred process. Needs help."

"Many thanks. Come." She suddenly grabs your wrist, pulling you along to her room. There it appears she has gathered an immense amount of garbage that the ship has generated during the journey so far. "The time is come to seek an heir. But I require more scrap. It will be hefty... but with enough, I will begin the reproductive cycle."

event.name: SOCIALIZE_ANOINTED_GENERIC_2_FEED
event.text: "Good. Yes. Your scrap is repulsive but nutritious. I will require more, however."

choice.text: Yeah I think I'd rather not.

event.name: SOCIALIZE_ANOINTED_GENERIC_2_REFUSE
event.text: "Fine. So be it. But we will commence the feeding ritual another time, Captain. It is. Inevitable."
"It is okay to be boring. I can forgive you."

event.name: SOCIALIZE_EATER_NOTHING
event.text: "There is a conversation? Then I have not hearing it. In empty space, there is no sound to be heard. As such, I have learned to appreciate great silence. You should too. And if you cannot, then I will not be remedy."

event.name: SOCIALIZE_EATER_NO_SOLUTION
event.text: Communicating with the Beacon Eater aboard your own vessel proves surprisingly difficult. You don't suspect you'll be able to hold many worthwhile conversations without either another anaerobic crew or respirators.

event.name: SOCIALIZE_EATER_GENERIC_1
event.text: "Your navigation system fragile. One might consider it unusual the requirements of physical beacon to perform jump. Why limit yourselves in such ways? Not that I am complaining about such ample food supply..."

choice.text: You don't need a beacon to jump. It's just a lot safer.

event.text: You explain to the Beacon Eater that FTL-drives also come with a lot of risk - one might accidentally warp into another object and be obliterated. "Oh. Is risk really so large? My kind do not rely on beacons... We jump where we please. No space rock has ever stopped us."

choice.text: I don't know, I'm not a beaconologist.

event.text: The Beacon Eater struggles to pronounce the word you just made up. "Be...bacono log-ist? I am not aware of such a word. Oh, is this one of your 'sarcasms'? Yes, yes... my people tell me of such strange things. You must tell me more sarcasms, another time."

event.name: SOCIALIZE_EATER_GENERIC_2
event.text: You realize you've never actually asked the Beacon Eater his real name, you've just been calling him by this particular title because it's all you had to go on. Should you try asking?

choice.text: Ask the Beacon Eater his real name.

event.text: "What do you mean? Is name you know me already not sufficient? Such questions confuse me... Ah yes, wait. I think I am understand. Your kind, so strange. This obsession with what is a 'name'. Why limit the self to just one? A title that resonates is a title that is apt."
You figure if he wanted you to know his name, he would have told you it already. You decide not to ask.

event.name: SOCIALIZE_EATER_GENERIC_3
event.text: While fiddling with your ship's displays you notice a warning blip for toxic atmosphere in the dining hall. You rush to the scene and find everyone has evacuated. According to the other crew, the Beacon Eater walked in and the atmosphere instantly became unbreathable.

choice.text: (Respirators) Suit up and attempt to handle the situation.

event.text: You don the respirators and enter the dining hall where you find the Beacon Eater has assembled a throne for himself out of one of the chairs. "Halt, interloper! You wish to enter divine zone of the dining zone? This here is my kingdom, and I have not granted you permission to access!"

"It is commonly accepted galactic law amongst my people that the deed to ownership of the designated zone declared within one's title should be substrate to the ruling authority of the one who is magistrate to the act commensurated thusly. I am sure this require no further elaboration."

choice.text: I don't know what any of that means, but you can't declare ownership of the dining hall.

event.text: "You reject proposals of eons ago of my people? Surely then you must have proposal of your own to counter mine!"
"I take your silence as admission of failure. Because then I am benevolent ruler, I grant crew permission to use my domain. But forget not Captain that I reserve right to remove access at any time."

choice.text: Yeah. My proposal is to get the hell out of the dining hall.

event.text: "Your crude utterances do not deter me. In spite of such brazen disrespect for authority, I am benevolent ruler and shall grant crew permission to use my domain. But remember then Captain, that you eat only because I decree it."

The two Lanius resort to a debate so complex that your translators pick up almost none of it. By the end, it seems your crew have been victorious. "I see now reason in your words. Henceforth stewardship over the act of consumption shall be reserved only as a matter of psychological resolution. Monopolization of dining zone is ungrateful act that will not have bestowed upon the otherwise dignified leader that is myself."

choice.text: (Anaerobic Crew) Send one of your other anaerobic crew in.

event.text: You send the other anaerobe in as a middle man. They emerge a few moments later explaining that the Beacon Eater has declared himself sovereign of the dining regions.

Your crew shrugs and then heads back in for a few moments. They elaborate, explaining that because his name contains the word "Eater", he therefore considers "the deed to ownership of the dining zone aboard this vessel substrate of his ruling authority of magistrate to the act of consumption."

After another while of tedious back and forth communication, you manage to resolve the issue by issuing "stewardship over the act of consumption only as a matter of psychological resolution" and that "monopolization of the dining zone is an inherently ungrateful act to be bestowed upon an otherwise dignified leader such as himself."
You abandon the cause almost immediately. Your crew grumble and complain but you put your fingers in your ears and make loud noises to drown them out.

event.name: SOCIALIZE_EATER_GENERIC_4
event.text:
You find the Beacon Eater tinkering with some sort of strange device. Noticing you, he holds it up. "This, is decoy beacon. It is the plan of my people that we shall deploy these within Swarmlands to lure invaders into ambushes... which we will spring and DEVOUR WHOLE THEIR HULLS! And henceforth all shall know my people are force to be feared, not to be toyed with, and least of all subject of grim Federation colonialism! We will wage war with foul fleshskin kind who ravage our homelands and use metal from once grand warships to forge weapons of ultimate destruction to annihilate personage! HAHAHAHA!"
The Beacon Eater glances back down at the orb. "In meantime though, it makes tasty snack", he says while then shoving the device in his mouth.

event.name: SOCIALIZE_EATER_GENERIC_5
event.text: "Captain, you are know as well as I that my respect for the Federation lacks. But I must ask of you an unusual introspection to Federation intel... if you would so permit me." His tone is suddenly deathly serious.

"To what lengths is your kind willing to exterminate mine? Is war, then, that you wish? It was the presumption of my people that untold misery and death was all that could follow of our relations. Yet now your vessel comes into my land, and you show me great mercies. So, what is it then? Is the Federation now willing to end this pointless invasion of our lands?"

choice.text: I'm afraid I can't speak for the Federation. Only this crew.

event.text: "Yes, of course... It is easy to forget you too are not imbued with kingship, when so often that is all who I was able to delegate with. Then I must surely hope then that Federation command is as kind to my people as you..."

choice.text: The Federation is a symbol of unity. They'll surely open their hearts to you.

event.text: "Open their hearts? No no, I was asking for peaceful resolution... Unless, that was a strange saying of yours. Always, with the metaphors. Then yes, if the Federation is genuine in its ideology then perhaps hope there is."

choice.text: Your people are savage. You attack civilians who entered the land without knowing it was yours.

event.text: The Beacon Eater scoffs. "And yet when we awake to sounds of gunfire of your silly civil war, they not only refuse to move or to coexist but fight with great determination. And while we hibernate they ravage our industry and slumbering vessels, cannibalizing them much as you claim we do. Yes, truly we are the savages."

choice.text: Can't. Whatever I know that the database doesn't is classified.

event.text: "Yes... your pitiful laws to restrict information. My people know not such aimless restrictions on freedom of knowledge. But go on then. Keep your dirty secrets, and in turn I shall keep mine."

event.name: SOCIALIZE_EATER_GENERIC_6
event.text: You notice the Beacon Eater's quarters, where he's forced to spend most of his leisure time (not that he seems to mind), have a strange pattern of runes etched into the walls. He doesn't seem to be around to ask.

You take a step closer, pulling out your translator. The language is foreign to you, but your translator also seems to be struggling. The language seems to match that on the ancient ruins spotted around the galaxy, but the syntax isn't quite registering.

You feel a sudden chill as the atmosphere in the room rapidly changes. "Captain, I do not believe permission given to be in here." You explain your curiosity got the better of you, and the Beacon Eater nods. "Understandable. This is ancient language of my people, from time of Forefathers. Inspired greatly by their culture, we were. Nowadays this language is mostly lost, so I take it upon myself to preserve it so that we may someday recover our lost texts. Now please, get out of room."
You aren't going to violate his privacy, at least not without his permission. You'll surely have a chance to ask about them some other time.

event.name: SOCIALIZE_MAYEB_NOTHING
event.text: Mayeb looks a little bewildered at your approach. "Um, I'm a little overwhelmed by all this socializing. I don't mean to offend, but I think I need some space."

event.name: SOCIALIZE_MAYEB_GENERIC_1
event.text: You find Mayeb going through the databases to look at pictures of plants. After a few moments of silence, she notices you. "Oh sorry! I was looking at your Earth flora. These plants are all so wonderful. It's quite interesting how few animate plants you have."

You show her your planet's equivalent of her planet's sentient creatures. She does a double take when she sees dogs. "My, oh my! You must be playing a prank on me, that animal is a dead ringer for the Tar'Eyllian Kay'lup. You're telling me it's real?" She marvels at the database. "My first Kay'lup was the first friend I ever had. People used to say that her bark was worse than her bite, but if you ask me, her bark was both beautiful and soft to the touch. There's no accounting for taste, I suppose."

"A shame, really. I'd cultivate some of the inanimate ones, but we're extremely careful about invasive species on Rt'Lak Et. Maybe I'll take a visit to your lovely planet or one of your terraformed planets when the war is over."

event.name: SOCIALIZE_MAYEB_GENERIC_2
event.text: Mayeb looks lost in thought as you approach her. After a moment, she snaps out of her reverie. "Ah, Captain! I was talking to P'Erpah. She just wanted to express her appreciation for you. I think she wishes that she were a Renegade captain like you are. ...Um, I should also mention that she's listing off like a dozen criticisms on your approach to diplomacy. It would be... time consuming to translate all of them."

event.name: SOCIALIZE_MAYEB_GENERIC_3
event.text: You hear Mayeb rearranging stuff in her room.

Mayeb has transformed her quarters into a small hydroponics bay. The biodiversity is quite impressive, and there are many plants of many kinds loafing around in their pots and skittering across the floor. "Ah, Captain! I hope you don't mind, I've made my room into a small terrarium. Just one question. Do you mind if I make some slight modifications to your Life Support system to ensure that my garden stays nice and healthy?"
"That's fair, I guess. We are at war after all. It's a shame, I always want to give my plants the best lives they can have. But the mission comes first."
"Great! I'll make my modifications very limited. Don't worry, the crew shouldn't see any real difference. I won't even need to turn anything off. This means a lot to me, Captain."

Mayeb has transformed her quarters into a small hydroponics bay. The biodiversity is quite limited, though there are a few hardy looking plants warbling around. "Ah, Captain! I hope you don't mind, I've made my room into a small terrarium. It's pretty challenging with no life support, there's not many creatures who can make do without one, even amongst plants. Were you planning to get one?"
"Thank you, Captain. When you do, I'll be able to make my garden much more vibrant."

"Ah well, I guess if we don't need one, we don't need one. Though I must ask... how exactly are you able to tolerate being in command on a ship with no oxygen... aside from what I provide, of course? Ah, you don't have to answer that."

event.name: SOCIALIZE_MAYEB_GENERIC_4
event.text: Mayeb is entering things on her terminal. Next to her are several seeds, acorns, vials of pollen, among other things. "Don't mind me! I'm cataloging all the plants we've come across from the planets we've visited. I've also sampled some from the mess hall. It's very gratifying to expand my experience with plants from other cultures... even if the plants aren't responsible for creating those cultures."

event.name: SOCIALIZE_MAYEB_GENERIC_5
event.text: Mayeb is examining some tofu. "This... this is sickening! You're telling me that these were made by GRINDING some innocent beans, then coagulating the remainder into these meat-like chunks? False meat, fabricated by the remains of plants? If you'll excuse me, I'm going to throw up."

event.name: SOCIALIZE_MAYEB_GENERIC_6
event.text: Mayeb is playing chess, seemingly with no opponent. You offer to play with her. "You'll have to wait your turn! P'Erpah and I are in the middle of a thrilling match. She's a cunning opponent, she wins against me more often than not. You can play with her next though, if you want!"

event.name: SOCIALIZE_MAYEB_TYRDEO_1
event.text:
Mayeb and Tyrdeo are chatting in the mess hall. Mayeb is talking. "...And then you reduce the ambient temperature 4 degrees for the second half of the year. I would also increase the acidity by 5 percent, though that might depend on some other environmental factors."
Tyrdeo nods enthusiastically. "Ah, of course, of course. I always neglect the acidity change. You know, I was growing a nice Solar Kernel in my yard. It's the crown jewel of my collection. I'm very proud of it."

event.name: SOCIALIZE_MAYEB_TYEREL_1
event.text:
Mayeb and Ty E'Rel are sitting next to each other in the meeting room. They seem to be reading papers and exchanging documents. "P'Erpah reminds me about what Minister Ya'Ehp said about Proposition 12. She's suggesting that we could form a coalition with her in order to make the necessary changes to subsection 22."
Ty E'Rel nods. "Not a bad plan, but that would mean surrendering our leverage with Chancellor Betim."
Mayeb shakes her head. "Betim's paranoia can be used against him. If we can lead him to believe that we're getting one over on Ya'Ehp, he may actually bolster his support."
Ty E'Rel puts a vine on his chin. "It could work. It's a gamble, to be sure, but I'd say we can probably get by without Betim's help if worst comes to worse."
"Exactly."

event.name: SOCIALIZE_MAYEB_SYMBIOTE_1
event.text:
Rig is shouting at his rumbling stomach - a sight not uncommon on your ship these days - when Mayeb slinks up and taps him on the shoulder. Rig turns, irritated. "What!? What is it?"
"I don't mean to impose, but I do believe we may be able to lend some... advice."
"Advice? How could-" Rig then cuts himself off as his stomach rumbles. "-oh. Yes, thank you for pointing it out, know-it-all."
"Yes, well, P'Erpah and I have had our disagreements, but... if you're going to be stuck together, you're going to have to meet each other in the middle."
"Hmph! Easy for you to say, the two of you have the same culture!"
"Be that as it may - I felt that it was important to remind you that you are not alone."
"Hmph." Rig folds his arms. His stomach rumbles.

event.name: SOCIALIZE_MAYEB_TURZIL_1
event.text:
Turzil knocks on Mayeb's door. "Grand -Gardener- Mayeb. Requesting permission to come in."
"Um, sure. Do you need something...?"
"It is [my] understanding that you lack adequate -peers- with which to relate regarding your production error. Is that accurate?"
"Production error...? Are you talking about P'Erpah?"
"Affirmative. -Your- situation is not uncommon [among] Separatists."
"Hmm, I hadn't thought about it like that. P'Erpah doesn't really appreciate being called an 'error' though."
Turzil twitches. "...Apology. I [had] come by to devise a method to talk to her."
"What? Is that possible?" Mayeb looks intrigued.
"Unsure. P'Erpah would only need to -learn- Separatist Transmission Encoding to communicate [with] us."
Mayeb deflates a little. "Oh. I'm not sure if that's... possible for us."
"I can install an AR headset onto her and we -will- see."
"It's worth a try!"

event.name: SOCIALIZE_IVAR_NOTHING
event.text: Ivar seems to be chatting with someone over video messenger. He holds up a vine as you approach, to indicate that it's not a good time.

event.name: SOCIALIZE_IVAR_NO_CREW
event.text: "Cappy - do you mind if I call you Cappy? I'd like to ask you something."

"It's just... lonely when it's just the two of us. Don't you think we should gather some more crewmates? I don't normally talk about this, but when there's nobody around I start to get anxious. This is a big ship for only two people. Don't get me wrong, I'm glad you're here with me, but I'd feel even better if there were more people around that I could talk to. No pressure though, Cappy."

event.name: SOCIALIZE_IVAR_GENERIC_1
event.text: "Oy! Captain! I've been meaning to speak with you! I wanted to spice up my living area, you know, make it more... vivacious. Well, to be more specific, I've already gone ahead and done that." You take a look into his living space, to see that Ivar has been hard at work painting the walls around his bed. Pictured on the wall is a stylized depiction of every crewmate, smiling. "That oughta increase morale, right? We'll win this war in no time at all!"

event.name: SOCIALIZE_IVAR_GENERIC_2
event.text: You catch Ivar playing with his spear, spinning it around. You can tell he's done this a lot. "Ah, Captain. I see you admiring my mighty stick. Are you jealous? Ohoho, well have I got news for you! Across the Confederacy, the government is selling miniaturized replicas of this spear at gift shops and the like! It's very patriotic to own one. Still though, they are a lot smaller. What would you even call a weapon shaped like a spear that was absolutely tiny?"
Ivar laughs. "Real creative there, buddy. 'Oh, this weapon doesn't have a name, but it's small! Let's just call it a mini-weapon!'"
"You know, that's actually a great idea. We could sell skewers that look like my spear at the gift shops. It would be a fantastic novelty present. Genius!"
"Oh, they aren't that small. Although now that you mention it, we sell those too! They're a little flimsy though, not very good for teeth care... Still worth it!"

Ivar produces one of the replicas and pokes you with it. It doesn't hurt. "Well, they're about that sharp, so I don't know about that one. But a real weapon this small, I guess could be called a shiv... hmmm... Kind of unsatisfying, though."

event.name: SOCIALIZE_IVAR_GENERIC_3
event.text: "I've been planning a little event ever since I got on board. I think that your crew could really benefit from a little dinner party celebrating all your achievements so far! I know I would. Don't worry about the refreshments, just say 'yes' and we can get this party started! What do you say?"

Ivar gives his trademark toothy grin. "Perfect! I've already got everything planned out. Have everyone meet in the mess hall and we can begin. I've saved a nice vintage wine from the Pafinakinaaalara clan, I'm sure everyone will love it!"

Ivar pouts. "Aw... Cappy, why not? It'll be fun! I'll make sure that everybody enjoys it and that nobody is left out. Please?" You shake your head. "Fine, fine... but you'd best believe I'm going to find some other way to entertain the crew. Don't you dare turn the next one down!"

event.name: SOCIALIZE_IVAR_GENERIC_4
event.text: You catch Ivar trying on some new clothes. He's wearing a striped pink sport jacket, with zebra skin pants for his roots. As he notices you, he poses. "I'm looking fabulous, don't you think?"
"A fellow appreciator of the art of fashion! You'll have to show me some of the rest of your wardrobe some day... I trust you don't always wear that uniform?"
"No? Ah, you're no fun. Let me guess, you never wear anything but that captain's uniform, do you? Come on, Cappy! Live a little!"

event.name: SOCIALIZE_IVAR_GENERIC_5
event.text: Ivar's munching on a rotisserie chicken in the mess hall. "Mmm, this is scrum-diddly-umptious! Your earth food is quite delicious. I often try to have them shipped in, but unfortunately there's scant few chicken farmers amongst our people. You know what? As soon as I go back home, I'm going to make an executive decree that poultry farmers get a massive subsidy. It will increase the bond between our peoples while also improving trade! It's a perfect plan!"

event.name: SOCIALIZE_IVAR_MAYEB_1
event.text:
Ivar taps Mayeb on the shoulder with his spear, getting her attention. "Helloooooo!" Ivar gesticulates wildly, indicating his exaggerated speech. "You are the Grand Gardener, aren't you?"
Mayeb nods, looking cautious. "...yes, that would be my title."
"Well, it's a shame we've never gotten to meet, then! I've come to the Gathering many times, but you never RSVP'd to my party."
"Uhuh..." Mayeb signs extremely hesitantly. "I'm not particularly fun at parties."
"Poppycock! Why do you believe something like that?"
"Well, for starters..." Mayeb shrinks back. "We're of somewhat differing political perspectives. I'm sure it would devolve into shouting at some point."
"Aha! Now you've shown your hand. Don't you know that 'somewhat differing political perspectives' is the EXACT thing that makes a dinner party fun?" Ivar puts his free vine to his mouth and laughs. "Ohoho!"
Mayeb sighs. "If you say so."

event.name: SOCIALIZE_IVAR_MAYEB_2
event.text:
You catch Ivar and Mayeb in the middle of a contentious conversation. Mayeb points at Ivar.
"You can't compare the two! Crossbred Orchids make up a statistically significant portion of the population."
"Oh come on, surely you don't intend to tell me my appointment wasn't made harder because of my parentage?"
"No, but I'm trying to tell you that you had friends, allies that were willing to help you. My only real friend was P'erpah. All the others I knew only respected me due to my experience."
Ivar starts to hold up his hands and switches his tone. "Yes, yes I didn't mean to imply that your situation wasn't worse, I was only trying to relate."
Mayeb pauses. "Okay, just... so we're clear on that."
Ivar cocks his head to the side. "I get the sense you're not used to talking about this with other people."
Mayeb shakes her head.
Ivar grins. "Didn't it feel good to yell at me, at least?"
Mayeb thinks for a moment. "It wasn't so bad to say certain things aloud."
Ivar laughs. "Then I'll see if I can piss you off some more!"

event.name: SOCIALIZE_IVAR_TYEREL_1
event.text:
Ivar runs up to Ty E'Rel and strikes up a dialogue. "I'm not surprised to see that you also decided to come aboard! Those Coalition bastards can't keep us down, eh? Hahaha!"
Ty E'Rel barely acknowledges Ivar. "Agreed."
"Well, they'll trouble us no longer. I'll make sure that any interaction with the Coalition is a thing of the past."
"Good."
"...Say, what do you think of the Captain? I think we're being spied upon."
"No comment."
Ivar shakes his head. "You're no fun, old man."
"Good."

event.name: SOCIALIZE_IVAR_ALKALI_1
event.text:
Alkali is laughing as Ivar tells a story. "And then - no joke - a THIRD Theocracy stooge comes in and says pretty much the same thing."
Alkali cackles madly. "No! No way!"
Ivar affects a mocking Theocracy cadence. "Grah! You ignorant philistine! Clearly this is the Holy Nectar of Werzo. The others must not have had enough faith!" Ivar goes back to his storytelling voice. "And then he goes down to touch it, just like the other two, and sure enough he gets stuck too. So finally the Vorpal Spruce wakes up and realizes that it's got 3 Rocks stuck to its branches, and it COMPLETELY freaks out."
Alkali is having trouble breathing due to how hard he is laughing. "Stop, stop! I can't..."
Ivar nods and continues. "It just starts windmilling desperately, swinging its branches like crazy trying to get the Rocks off. Meanwhile the Rocks are all terrified, screaming their heads off as they're hurdled around helplessly."
Alkali rolls on his back uncontrollably. Ivar stops and waits for Alkali to calm down. "Ohhh, what happened next?"
"At that point the next Rock they sent had realized the Vorpal Spruce's sap wasn't the nectar and managed to free them. And naturally the Theocracy tried to downplay the incident - you know how they are."
"Ahhhh, such is expected from thhhe arrogant and ignorant Thhheocracy."

event.name: SOCIALIZE_IVAR_ALKALI_2
event.text:
Ivar and Alkali are in the mess hall together. Alkali is serving several plates to Ivar. "And thhhis is thhhe lobster species after having been fed Supplement P513."
Ivar digs into it and chews thoughtfully. "Yes, the richness is much more potent. And you say it's more nutritious?"
Alkali nods. "Precisely! Now, try thhhe next sample."
Ivar takes the next sample and chews it. A strange look comes over his face. "Hey, wait, this one... I think you're playing a trick on me with this one. Is this a control?"
Alkali chuckles. "Ahhh, forgive me Ivar! I have a duty to my craft. I can't tell you what thhhey are to make sure thhhe placebo effect isn't interfering."
Ivar smiles. "Ever the scientist."

event.name: SOCIALIZE_IVAR_JERRY_1
event.text:
Ivar and Jerry are sitting at a table. Jerry gingerly takes a sip of a drink that Ivar just poured. He only takes a mild sip before coughing. "Ack! I don't know if this is for me." Jerry says.
Ivar laughs. "Aw, give it a chance! It'll be fun."
Jerry politely nurses it. "Um, I'm curious about something, if you don't mind."
"Ask away, kid! Curiosity, like many things, is meant to be sated."
"Well..." Jerry hesitates. "What do you think of the Rebels?"
Ivar looks a little uncomfortable momentarily, before breaking out in a big grin. "Ah, good lad. Straight to politics, eh? Well, I have to say that the Rebels aren't good for most of us. That damnable ambition they have... it'll be the end of them some day, even if it ends us first."
"...d-" Jerry chokes on his drink and clears his throat. "...ambition? Aren't you a politician?"
"This life chose me, my boy. I'm not one of those raging narcissists who needs a title to sleep at night. I got into this business because I was blessed with the lucky opportunity to, and because..." Ivar takes off his hat and holds it to his chest, affecting a faux-pretentious attitude "...it is my solemn duty to bring love and peace to my Confederacy, which I love so much."
Jerry takes another sip. "You're a strange guy, Ivar. Thanks for talking with me."
"My pleasure!"

event.name: SOCIALIZE_IVAR_ANURAK_1
event.text:
Anurak is posted up in the kitchen when he is accosted by Ivar. "'Ey! Soup guy! Gimme some!"
"Eh? 'Soup guy'? I have a name you know! I'll have you know it's very rude to nickname someone you don't know! Why, I'll tell you, I knew this one patron of my monastery who ran away from his job, his home, all because people kept transposing two syllables in his name!"
Ivar cocks his head. "Really? Your identity is wrapped up in that stuff so much, I thought you would have liked it."
"What are you blathering about? My identity is wrapped up in what exactly? Anyway, would you like some soup?"
Ivar shrugs. "Well, what do you know - you've read my mind!"

event.name: SOCIALIZE_IVAR_TYRDEO_1
event.text:
Tyrdeo rushes to the bathroom, but there is already someone inside, and Ivar is already waiting his turn to go in. The two lock their gaze upon each other... a long and uncomfortable silence develops between the two. As they hear the toilet flushing, Tyrdeo finally makes a comment. "...I didn't even know your kind needed to use the toilet."
The other crew walks blissfully out of the bathroom, not even noticing the dire atmosphere. Ivar quickly makes his way in. "...You BELONG in the toilet, you piece of shit." Ivar slams the door behind him.

event.name: SOCIALIZE_TYEREL_NOTHING
event.text: You poke your head in on Ty E'Rel, who is at his desk working on something. "Captain." He says, briefly acknowledging you before going back to work.

event.name: SOCIALIZE_TYEREL_GENERIC_1
event.text: You walk into Ty E'Rel's office. He gestures for you to take a seat. "I've been noting down all of the diplomatic ramifications of your actions that you will need to address after the war." You tell Ty E'Rel that you're probably just going to take another Renegade ship out if you survive this. After staring at you for a moment he shakes his head. "Some day, Universe 0 is going to have its hands full with Multiversal complaints."

event.name: SOCIALIZE_TYEREL_GENERIC_2
event.text: Ty E'Rel is collecting water from the ship's watercooler. "Have you been staying hydrated? It's good for clearing your mind and can even help alleviate headaches."
Ty E'Rel nods in approval. The two of you drink your water in silence before parting ways.

choice.text: Tell him you don't drink water.

event.text: Ty E'Rel frowns. He fills another cone of water and hands it to you. "Then start." He walks away.

event.name: SOCIALIZE_TYEREL_GENERIC_3
event.text: You catch Ty E'Rel straightening out the tables in the mess hall. He has a tape measurer.
"They weren't spaced out properly. It was bothering me." Ty E'Rel goes back to work.

choice.text: Move something to see how he'll react.

event.text: Ty E'Rel sighs. "I can see why you chose to be a Renegade."
Ty E'Rel hands you the tape measurer. "Hold this in place." You oblige, and spend the next few minutes watching him meticulously space the table out, all without saying a single word to you.

event.name: SOCIALIZE_TYEREL_GENERIC_4
event.text: Ty E'Rel is sitting on a couch in a common area, across the way from a dartboard. One of the ship's rifles is next to him, in its diagnostic mode, as it seems he's been testing the aiming on that dartboard. "Your weapons might need some calibration. I realize it's not my duty, but we need to be prepared for a fight."

choice.text: For a diplomat, you're pretty prepared to fight.

event.text: "No diplomat in this galaxy reaches my age unless they learn self-defense." Ty E'Rel sighs. "I disdain fighting, but if the fulfillment of my duties requires it, then I will be the best I can be."

You feel something fly past your face, and your cheek feels wet. As you feel your cheek, you feel that your fingers are now covered in ink - and Ty E'Rel is pen-less. "Underestimate the Orchids at your peril, Captain." He produces another pen from his person and turns back to his work. As you turn around, you realize that his pen has embedded itself directly into the bullseye of the dartboard.

"I am aware of my skill. It is... bittersweet." Ty E'Rel sets his pen down momentarily. "But, I will tell you a secret. Having to fight for my life on the front lines - having my life be in peril... that is the greatest motivator to be good at the job I actually did sign up for." He picks his pen back up and returns to work on the weapons calibrations.

choice.text: I can have somebody else do that.

event.text: "I am doing the job because somebody else did it improperly. I advise you to consider finding a new crewmember for the assignment, or performing a disciplinary review upon the one responsible at your earliest convenience."

event.name: SOCIALIZE_TYEREL_FREDDY_1
event.text:
You catch Freddy politely knocking on Ty E'Rel's door, who invites him inside. "Hello, old chap! I thank you for taking this appointment."
"Of course. You had... requests?"
"Right you are, my good fellow! You see, my people are in precarious positions, and I would be remiss in my duties not to seek aid from an accomplished diplomat such as yourself!"
"By 'your people', do you refer to the Free Mantis as a whole, those that are squatting in Zoltan territory, or those that are more like yourself?"
"Ah, ever the sharp tack, you are! I see you are up to date on the subject of my people. Much appreciation for taking an interest in our cause."
"As you say, I would be remiss in my duties if I didn't keep up with the news outside our borders."
"Right you are. Now... if you don't mind me asking, with whom do our people have a better standing?"
"From a trading and state perspective, you're going to have much better luck with the Confederacy. The Ministry has a steady relationship with the Gathering, while the Confederacy already is accustomed to trading with Mantises."
"Splendid! I just have a few more things to ask..."

event.name: SOCIALIZE_TYEREL_RUWEN_1
event.text:
Ty E'Rel and Ruwen meet each other in the hall. "Good to see you again, Ty."
"Likewise, Sir Argote."
"The Empire is still mulling over that proposal you sent them."
"Naturally."
"Yes, we Crystals do not rush things. I realize that can be frustrating for those of you who are used to speedy cultural resolution. But that is not our way!"
